Re: License #: CP300201172
Dear Ms. Villegas:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/10/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central
registry
(4) A volunteer or contractor who is listed on the central
registry as a perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect
may not have unsupervised contact with children.
One of five interns did not have clearances completed prior to beginning their
internship.
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
(3) An agency shall provide the licensee an application
for renewal of the license and document the action not
less than 60 calendar days before the expiration date of
the license. A renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending recommendation for
disciplinary action of the license.
One of three foster home files did not have documentation that an application was
provided at least 60 days prior to license expiration.
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
2

One of three licensing files did not have a signed Foster Parent Agency Agreement.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period.
One of three licensing files held a reevaluation that did not include information from
the caseworkers that had children placed in the home during that review period.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the
reevaluation. The placement specifications must include
all the following:
(a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic background,
and characteristics of children preferred by the
applicants.
Two of three licensing files held reevaluations that did not include the required
information. Specifically, information regarding race, ethnic background, SOGIE,
and special characteristics they would or would not accept.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within
45 calendar days after receipt of the information. If
additional time is required, then the agency shall inform
the foster parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension
and the expected length of the extension. The total time
for the completion of the investigation may not exceed 90
calendar days without written approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
One of one special evaluations did not have written documentation the evaluation
would last longer than 45 days.
3

In addition, while the agency had a 90-day approval letter by the Chief
Administrator, it was not completed until after the evaluation had already exceed 90
days.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated: (i) A
comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
One of eight foster care files did not have an initial medical exam completed within
30 days of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
One of eight foster care files did not have a dental exam completed within 90 days
of entering care.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information
4

in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.
One of eight foster care files held one treatment plan that was not signed by the
parent to indicate they reviewed and received the report.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/1/24 Renewal, CAP approved 3/25/24
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
One of eight foster care cases did not have sibling visits documented.

(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Licensing application for foster homes- The agency was advised to document
via a letter or email in CWLM when an application is provided to a foster
parent, to ensure it is clear the application was provided at least 60 days prior
to license expiration.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Consultation was not requested or required during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
Maltreatment in Care
There was one substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this review
period.
There is one incident of corporate punishment during this review period. SER
2024SEC0001569 was initiated on 5/1/2024 regarding an allegation that an
altercation occurred between a foster parent and a foster child. It was further
6

alleged a foster parent and foster child had an inappropriate sexual relationship.
The licensed foster parents were found to be in violation of rule 9201(1e)
Applicant/Licensee Qualifications, 9404(4a) Behavior Management, 9201(3)
Applicant/Licensee Qualifications, 9301(1) Maintenance, and 9403(1a) Foster
Parent Duties. Revocation of the license was recommended. The evaluation was
completed thoroughly with an appropriate recommendation.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency had one corrective action plan (CAP) approved on 3/25/24 as a result
of the 3/1/24 renewal evaluation. The agency was cited at that time regarding
change of placement documentation, overdue physicals/dentals and
immunizations, PATP signatures, and missing monthly home visits. The agency
reported successful implementation of the CAP and improvement in all areas.
During the current review, only one repeat violation was found from the 3/25/24
CAP, regarding treatment plan signatures. While there was improvement in
decreasing occurrences of missing signatures, the agency will continue to work
toward compliance in this area. In addition, the three repeat violations from the
4/27/23 Interim (CAP approved 5/3/23) will need to be addressed in a new CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment dated 2/10/25 was reviewed and discussed
on-site. The Chief Administrator reported the agency improved compliance in
several areas during this report period through the use of updated checklists,
increased monitoring and follow-up of medical and dental due dates,
placement/replacement checklist, utilizing data reports, supervisors using
reminders for workers, and supervisory review up uploaded documents. Chief
Administrator reported these activities have improved compliance and key
performance indicators in several areas. One barrier to compliance was identified
as a lack of medical and dental providers in the area. Chief Administrator reported
some disrupted/unplanned placement changes due to behavioral issues that
resulted in youth placement in detention and inpatient treatment. Chief
Administrator reported that when disrupted placements occurred, staff looked at
revisiting previous placements, identifying appropriate relatives, and attempted to
resolve any prior barriers to placement. Some systemic barriers include a lack of
mental health services in that area that can quickly engage with youth and families
to provide intensive and crisis services.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff Interviews
Three staff were interviewed on-site. All three staff reported they enjoy working at
the agency. One staff recently moved from a position in foster care, to licensing.
Staff reported they enjoy the change of pace and community outreach that comes
with recruitment activities. One foster care staff reported they have been a case
worker for a few years but continue to learn new things all the time. Another foster
care staff reported moving to the position from protective services and enjoying
7

the change. All three staff stated they had excellent supervisors that provide
support, direction, useful information, and answer all of their questions. Staff
reported they continue to receive useful training on a variety of subjects. Staff
stated that they appreciate they can brainstorm and vent with coworkers and count
on one another for assistance. None of the staff had any concerns or suggestions
for improvement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the Hillsdale County State of Michigan
building. The office has adequate space for staff to carry out their duties, as well
as space for clients to meet and visit. There is sufficient locking storage to secure
files as required.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one identified safety alert.
Safety Alert: During a visit on 12/18/24 the analyst noted a flotation device needed to
be placed near the lake. The foster parent was unable to locate one that was
previously placed.
Resolution: A safety plan was developed on 12/19/24. A flotation device was
immediately ordered and properly placed near the water once received. Licensing
staff viewed and verified compliance on 1/10/25. A photo was provided to DCWL for
verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
